item.title: Electrochemical Cell‐Free Biosensors for Antibody Detection
item.description: Angewandte Chemie International Edition, EarlyView.
item.dc:description: Programmable antigen‐conjugated gene circuits which, upon recognition of a target antibody, trigger the cell‐free transcription of an RNA sequence that can be consequently detected with a disposable electrochemical sensor, were designed by Sara Bracaglia, Simona Ranallo, and Francesco Ricci in their Research Article (DOI: 10.1002/anie.202216512). The cell‐free electrochemical biosensor allows the sensitive, specific, selective, and multiplexed detection of different antibodies in blood serum.
item.content:encoded: Programmable antigen-conjugated gene circuits which, upon recognition of a target antibody, trigger the cell-free transcription of an RNA sequence that can be consequently detected with a disposable electrochemical sensor, were designed by Sara Bracaglia, Simona Ranallo, and Francesco Ricci in their Research Article (DOI: 10.1002/anie.202216512). The cell-free electrochemical biosensor allows the sensitive, specific, selective, and multiplexed detection of different antibodies in blood serum.
item.dc:creator: Sara Bracaglia, Simona Ranallo, Francesco Ricci
item.dc:title: Electrochemical Cell‐Free Biosensors for Antibody Detection

item.source: Wiley: Angewandte Chemie International Edition: Table of Contents
item.title: Electronic Control of the Scholl Reaction: Selective Synthesis of Spiro vs Helical Nanographenes
item.description: Angewandte Chemie International Edition, EarlyView.
item.dc:description: Different electronic effects on the starting anthracene‐containing polyphenylene substrate (bottom) afford two different nanographenes under Scholl reaction conditions, namely, spironanographenes (R=H) on the left, and a helically arranged molecular nanographene having two orthogonal aromatic moieties linked by an octafluoroanthracene core (R=F) on the right. The different stability of the intermediate trityl cation and the concomitant gain of aromaticity decide the fate of the reaction, as explained by Israel Fernández, Nazario Martín et al. in their Research Article (DOI: 10.1002/anie.202215655).
item.content:encoded: Different electronic effects on the starting anthracene-containing polyphenylene substrate (bottom) afford two different nanographenes under Scholl reaction conditions, namely, spironanographenes (R=H) on the left, and a helically arranged molecular nanographene having two orthogonal aromatic moieties linked by an octafluoroanthracene core (R=F) on the right. The different stability of the intermediate trityl cation and the concomitant gain of aromaticity decide the fate of the reaction, as explained by Israel Fernández, Nazario Martín et al. in their Research Article (DOI: 10.1002/anie.202215655).
item.dc:creator: Patricia Izquierdo‐García, Jesús M. Fernández‐García, Josefina Perles, Israel Fernández, Nazario Martín
item.dc:title: Electronic Control of the Scholl Reaction: Selective Synthesis of Spiro vs Helical Nanographenes

item.source: Wiley: Angewandte Chemie International Edition: Table of Contents
item.title: Multilayered Ceramic Membrane with Ion Conducting Thin Layer Induced by Interface Reaction for Stable Hydrogen Production
item.description: Angewandte Chemie International Edition, EarlyView.
item.dc:description: Multilayered ceramic membranes with ion conducting dense thin layers are essential platforms for solid state electrochemical devices, gas separation membranes and sensors. In their Research Article (DOI: 10.1002/anie.202210485), Heqing Jiang et al. develop a new interface‐reaction‐induced reassembly approach for the direct fabrication of zirconia‐ or ceria‐based dense thin layers rooted in multilayered ceramic membranes that show robust and practical performance for upgrading fossil‐fuel‐derived hydrogen.
item.content:encoded: Multilayered ceramic membranes with ion conducting dense thin layers are essential platforms for solid state electrochemical devices, gas separation membranes and sensors. In their Research Article (DOI: 10.1002/anie.202210485), Heqing Jiang et al. develop a new interface-reaction-induced reassembly approach for the direct fabrication of zirconia- or ceria-based dense thin layers rooted in multilayered ceramic membranes that show robust and practical performance for upgrading fossil-fuel-derived hydrogen.
item.dc:creator: Guanghu He, Qianqian Lan, Mengke Liu, Guixuan Wu, Rafal E. Dunin‐Borkowski, Heqing Jiang
item.dc:title: Multilayered Ceramic Membrane with Ion Conducting Thin Layer Induced by Interface Reaction for Stable Hydrogen Production

item.source: Wiley: Angewandte Chemie International Edition: Table of Contents
item.title: Expanding the Toolbox of Target Directed Bio‐Orthogonal Synthesis: In Situ Direct Macrocyclization by DNA Templates
item.description: Angewandte Chemie International Edition, EarlyView.
item.dc:description: The DNA templated bio‐orthogonal synthesis of macrocyclic gene modulators is illustrated in the cover picture accompanying the Research Article (DOI: 10.1002/anie.202215245) by Jyotirmayee Dash and co‐workers. DNA secondary structures present in the telomere and oncogene promoter proximally orient bi‐functional alkyne and azide fragments, enabling bond formation via Cu‐free azide–alkyne cycloaddition in live cells. The high‐affinity DNA binding macrocyclic ligand efficiently suppresses oncogene expression in cancer cells.
item.content:encoded: The DNA templated bio-orthogonal synthesis of macrocyclic gene modulators is illustrated in the cover picture accompanying the Research Article (DOI: 10.1002/anie.202215245) by Jyotirmayee Dash and co-workers. DNA secondary structures present in the telomere and oncogene promoter proximally orient bi-functional alkyne and azide fragments, enabling bond formation via Cu-free azide–alkyne cycloaddition in live cells. The high-affinity DNA binding macrocyclic ligand efficiently suppresses oncogene expression in cancer cells.
item.dc:creator: Ritapa Chaudhuri, Thumpati Prasanth, Jyotirmayee Dash
item.dc:title: Expanding the Toolbox of Target Directed Bio‐Orthogonal Synthesis: In Situ Direct Macrocyclization by DNA Templates

item.title: Design and Manipulation of a Minimalistic Hydrocarbon Nanocar on Au(111)
item.description: Angewandte Chemie International Edition, EarlyView.
item.dc:description: A minimalistic hydrocarbon nanocar was synthesized, deposited on a Au(111) surface, and driven by a STM tip thanks to electrostatic interactions. This nanomachine was able to win the Nanocar Race II championship, as reported by Jonas Björk, Emilio M. Pérez, David Écija et al. in their Research Article (DOI: 10.1002/anie.202212395).
item.content:encoded: A minimalistic hydrocarbon nanocar was synthesized, deposited on a Au(111) surface, and driven by a STM tip thanks to electrostatic interactions. This nanomachine was able to win the Nanocar Race II championship, as reported by Jonas Björk, Emilio M. Pérez, David Écija et al. in their Research Article (DOI: 10.1002/anie.202212395).

item.source: Wiley: Angewandte Chemie International Edition: Table of Contents
item.title: A Disordered Rubik's Cube‐Inspired Framework for Sodium‐Ion Batteries with Ultralong Cycle Lifespan
item.description: Angewandte Chemie International Edition, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
Sodium‐ion batteries with fast‐charge capability and long lifespan could be applied in various sustainable energy storage systems, from personal devices to grid storage. Inspired by the disordered Rubik's cube, herein, Peng et al. report that the high‐entropy concept can lead to a very substantial improvement in the sodium storage properties of hexacyanoferrate. which has achieved impressive cycling stability over 50 000 cycles
Abstract Sodium‐ion batteries (SIBs) with fast‐charge capability and long lifespan could be applied in various sustainable energy storage systems, from personal devices to grid storage. Inspired by the disordered Rubik's cube, here, we report that the high‐entropy (HE) concept can lead to a very substantial improvement in the sodium storage properties of hexacyanoferrate (HCF). An example of HE‐HCF has been synthesized as a proof of concept, which has achieved impressive cycling stability over 50 000 cycles and an outstanding fast‐charging capability up to 75 C. Remarkable air stability and all‐climate performance are observed. Its quasi‐zero‐strain reaction mechanism and high sodium diffusion coefficient have been measured and analyzed by multiple in situ techniques and density functional theory calculations. This strategy provides new insights into the development of advanced electrodes and provides the opportunity to tune electrochemical performance by tailoring the atomic composition.
item.content:encoded:
Sodium-ion batteries with fast-charge capability and long lifespan could be applied in various sustainable energy storage systems, from personal devices to grid storage. Inspired by the disordered Rubik's cube, herein, Peng et al. report that the high-entropy concept can lead to a very substantial improvement in the sodium storage properties of hexacyanoferrate. which has achieved impressive cycling stability over 50 000 cycles


Abstract

Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) with fast-charge capability and long lifespan could be applied in various sustainable energy storage systems, from personal devices to grid storage. Inspired by the disordered Rubik's cube, here, we report that the high-entropy (HE) concept can lead to a very substantial improvement in the sodium storage properties of hexacyanoferrate (HCF). An example of HE-HCF has been synthesized as a proof of concept, which has achieved impressive cycling stability over 50 000 cycles and an outstanding fast-charging capability up to 75 C. Remarkable air stability and all-climate performance are observed. Its quasi-zero-strain reaction mechanism and high sodium diffusion coefficient have been measured and analyzed by multiple in situ techniques and density functional theory calculations. This strategy provides new insights into the development of advanced electrodes and provides the opportunity to tune electrochemical performance by tailoring the atomic composition.
item.dc:creator: Jian Peng, Bao Zhang, Weibo Hua, Yaru Liang, Wang Zhang, Yumeng Du, Germanas Peleckis, Sylvio Indris, Qinfen Gu, Zhenxiang Cheng, Jiazhao Wang, Huakun Liu, Shixue Dou, Shulei Chou
item.dc:title: A Disordered Rubik's Cube‐Inspired Framework for Sodium‐Ion Batteries with Ultralong Cycle Lifespan
